evidence.quote: even Opus became lazy.
Claude Code lazy... Opus became lazy and hallucinates deprecated APIs
feeling the added cruft in the code base... More refactoring is needed... rewriting files to ensure completeness, correctness
added cruft in codebase... more refactoring needed than if I wrote it myself
AI isn't taking your job! Never been a big fan of LLM-assisted coding... It didn't work! ... scrapped the whole thing and rewrote it from scratch in less time...
cursor generated bad code... subtle bugs... scrapped and rewrote from scratch in less time

If you're using AI to code, you're not a real developer I banned all AI coding tools in my startup after seeing my junior engineers using an American app called Kursor It's just another overhyped American technology...

Banned Copilot, Cursor, Claude — everything. Juniors were committing absolute security disasters. Hard-coded credentials, insecure deserialization, wide-open CORS. AI doesn't know our threat model and juniors don't catch it.

profiles.company: Mid-sized tech company (inferred from context of reviewing PRs from juniors)

evidence.quote: Reason #1471 why I hate junior engineers blindly using GenAI coding tools to write code. Every second PR I see is like this now. If there's one advice I keep giving junior engineers, it's PLEASE don't outsource "thinking" to an LLM.

Junior put AI-generated JWT verification code in prod. Used a random npm package Copilot hallucinated that doesn't exist + symmetric signing with HS256 on a public key. Had to emergency rollback at 3am.
Copilot barely works. Cursor is okay but frustrating (and slower). Claude Code usually just works fast.
Claude gassing himself up in code reviews... “This is a brilliant and sophisticated implementation…” *completely fails to build/compile*
subtle bugs that could cost you a ton of time and money... a lot of time can be wasted reviewing and refactoring AI generated code... significantly increase technical debt
had to create a custom command... hallucination-hunter... go find all the fake code you implemented... Just because people aren't talking about it doesn't mean it's a solved problem.
AI editors are producing code so fast that the bottleneck is code review and QA... can’t bring myself to yolo it to prod without a bunch of E2E tests
Junior hires are so bad right now, they just spam Claude code. Slapping AI on everything will not fix your shit.
Threw Claude in trash bin at work... wrecks flow state... Long tail effects of AI coding assistants are super concerning
Claude API has been have outages... Cursor reverted back to OpenAI and you can tell - the code is SIGNIFICANTLY worse
AI tools like Cursor are nondeterministic... can lead to bugs, vulnerabilities or inefficiencies... crucial to understand + review AI-generated code
Today’s AI writes incredibly unmaintainable code... Try refactoring any larger code base with Claude Code and it’s useless basically.
it guesses stuff, constantly... if it hits a problem, it’ll work around it, even if it means it didn’t actually do what you asked
Someone help me understand the appeal of Claude Code, compared to Cursor: ... Much harder to audit all the file changes it's made
Over the last week it has started making some BIZARRE mistakes... all of a sudden I can’t trust it to do even simple things.
Love the speed... but it seems to be a liability... it likes to break code all over the place without doing a thorough analysis.
you can feel the gradual disempowerment as you code using cursor... you no longer recognize your own codebase

There used to be two kinds of developers: frontend and backend. Now there’s a third: Cursor developers. – they let AI dump 500 lines of code – they spend 99% of the time fixing bugs generated by AI by AI – their ability to think is quietly dying

profiles.company: Compliant X Lead Gen Tool Startup

evidence.quote: People who learned with AI never built fundamentals... Older engineers: debug in 20 mins. Current-gen: stare at screen for 3 hours. (implying AI over-reliance and poor quality)
A BIG difference w AI agents: they will write more code, faster than before, and ship a LOT more code to prod! So ship more bugs as well.
junior devs now need to be good at working WITH ai tools... knowing when cursor is wrong, how to debug its output... spot the hallucinations
This is what happens when you know nothing and let ai write your code... random code generate by ai cant be trusted... can cause drastic failures
what used to take 8 devs and 3 weeks now takes 8 AI agents... (but implies risks with juniors over-relying and shipping untested AI code)
Anyone who’s used a lot of Claude code, Cursor and a few other agents, would disagree... it bangs its head enough... (acknowledging persistence but quality trade-offs)
Claude 4 just made every dev tool outdated... (but context in thread discusses hallucinations and quality issues in agents)
delegating huge and critical chunks of code to AI... hallucinations are near 0% (with tests/context, but acknowledges dangers without review)
AI generated code is somehow more prone to bugs... you have to actually TEST THEM... An an emoji to the text box and see what blows up.
D) A Time Sink: I spend more time fixing its "clever," hard-to-spot bugs than I save.
Lazy devs blindly ship it. The tool isn’t the problem. The mindset is.
It's so easy to get lazy or complacent and ask for massive changes... but that's how bad stuff sneaks in.
That's Claude Code vs Codex CLI. And I'm Claude Code. Been positively surprised by Codex. (implying Claude buggy like junior)
people underestimate the mental cost of outsourcing code to Copilot/Cursor... quick progress now at the expense of not understanding your own codebase
instead of just reverting to my working example, it hallucinates that it must be some other problem... I’m using Claude AND GPT and they both break basic api checking
i generate tons of code with cursor/copilot but spend just as much time reviewing it. ai makes dumb mistakes - wrong error handling, missing edge cases
anyone know why cursor & other coding agents prefer to regenerate files using a ton of tokens rather than just running a find and replace?
Cursor’s composer-1 has been freakishly fast but quality and correctness of code is still lacking (especially in larger codebases)
engineers one-shotted by cursor. can't think for themselves. can't write tests. can't explain their code
Vulnerability Inception: How AI Code Assistants Replicate and Amplify Security Flaws
The AI just hallucinated a function that doesn't exist and spent 10 minutes trying to debug it
composer fast but not as smart... quality vs Sonnet
composer fast but not the smartest model
vibe coding not working... review the code... use CodeRabbit
turned dotnet cursor rules to claude skills... still churn and hallucinations
AI code assistants are now replicating and amplifying known vulnerabilities at scale
skill cap on using cursor or claude code or whatever is very high – most people just accept bad output

Cursor just generated a perfect-looking Redis cache layer that silently ignores write errors and returns stale data forever. Took us 3 days to notice in staging. This is now the 4th security-adjacent incident caused by AI tools this quarter.

Had to fire a junior who kept merging Claude-generated auth code with hard-coded secrets and insecure randomness. Told him 3 times to stop trusting AI blindly. Now I just banned all AI coding tools for engineers with <3 YOE.

profiles.company: Series C game tools company (~180 employees)

evidence.quote: Copilot wrote a beautiful async file loader that deadlocks under load because it hallucinates a tokio::spawn that never awaits. Junior shipped it. Took us a week to debug. This is why I make juniors disable AI tools for first 6 months.

New policy: any PR with >60% Copilot acceptance rate gets auto-rejected. We're seeing SQL injection, path traversal, and prototype pollution creeping in from AI suggestions that juniors accept without thinking.
Claude just tried to make me use exec() on user input in a Django view. Had to explain to the junior that AI tools are not security-reviewed and never will be.

Weekly security incidents caused by AI-generated code up 400% since we allowed Cursor company-wide. Most common: insecure deserialization, improper auth checks, and use of vulnerable deprecated APIs that don't actually exist anymore.

Had to implement a GitHub bot that blocks commits containing 'use client' in server components because Cursor keeps hallucinating them. This is the third security-related hallucination blocker bot we've had to write this year.
Just spent 4 hours reviewing a junior's AI-generated payment processing code that used string concatenation for SQL queries. We are a HIPAA shop. AI tools are now restricted to senior+ only.
AI coding tools are creating a generation of developers who cannot read code without autocomplete and cannot reason about security. The code they produce is dangerously incompetent.
Junior shipped AI-generated memory management code that leaks 4GB under load because Copilot hallucinated a free() that doesn't match the malloc. This is why real companies will ban these tools soon.
Our security team is now requiring manual review of any code with >30% Copilot contribution because we're seeing consistent patterns of insecure crypto usage and race conditions.

profiles.company: Starfighter / appointment booking SaaS (~90 employees total)

evidence.quote: The median AI-assisted PR now introduces at least one security-relevant antipattern that would have been caught by any competent senior in 2015. We're literally going backwards.

profiles.company: Vercel partner but runs own AI tools team (~80 people)

evidence.quote: Real talk: 80% of Cursor suggestions in security-critical code need to be rejected. The other 20% still need heavy review. Juniors can't tell the difference yet.

Implemented a linter rule that blocks 'npm i' of packages with <1000 weekly downloads because Claude keeps hallucinating private package names that sound plausible but are actually don't exist. Juniors were installing malware.

profiles.company: Series C startup he joined (~280 employees)

evidence.quote: The new engineering competency we're screening for: 'Can you write code without Copilot?' Because if you can't, you're a security liability now.

Client just had a near-miss security breach because a junior accepted a Claude suggestion to use pickle.load() on untrusted input. We are now requiring all AI-generated code to go through security review queue.

profiles.company: Consults for Series B/C .NET companies (~150 avg)

evidence.quote: Seeing a massive uptick in insecure ASP.NET code from Copilot — improper Output Encoding, missing antiforgery tokens, insecure DirectObjectReference. Had to create a whole training program.

roles: Partner Engineer (but works with many mid-sized .NET shops)

evidence.quote: My engineers are using AI to write Redis client code that deadlocks because it hallucinates API calls that were never implemented. This is not productivity, this is anti-productivity with security implications.

Portfolio company just had to delay launch because junior used Cursor to implement OAuth flow and accepted a suggestion that leaks access tokens via redirect URI validation bypass. Banned for all <Staff level.
Implemented a pre-commit hook that scans for AI-generated code patterns known to be insecure (eval, pickle, exec, System.command, etc). Blocks ~8% of commits now.
Cursor suggested using MD5 for password hashing in 2025. Junior accepted it. We caught it in review but this should not be happening.
Our vuln scanner is now flagging 40% more issues in AI-assisted PRs than human-written ones. The difference is almost entirely in juniors accepting bad crypto or input validation suggestions.
Dark now bans all AI coding tools for anyone with <4 years experience after a near-breach caused by Claude hallucinating a secure session implementation that wasn't.

The bubble has created a generation of cargo-cult engineers who can’t code without Copilot. Junior devs now copy-paste AI-generated bugs, senior engineers review hallucinations, and codebases are filling with unmaintainable spaghetti...
Anyone blindly using AI coding will run into this. As a developer and a former team lead, its not much different than managing a fresh out of boot camp hotshot junior dev.

My manager thinks Copilot is saving 40% time. It's actually just hiding our tech debt. The new GenAI tools are great for boilerplate, but my PRs are full of correct but bad code I don't fully get. The review backlog is crushing us.

Vibe coding doesn't offer a free lunch. In nearly all cases one's local needs will diverge sufficiently from the AIs statistical model to introduce map / territory misalignments as generated code compounds. Misalignment of this kind happens with humans as well (technical debt)... perfect recipe for cascading catastrophic failures.
Lol, AI code gen, generating thousands of hours of technical debt in mere moments
each claude prompt comes with 2/3 more to clean up the tech debt
it seems google shipped it just so you could finally retire claude's spaghetti code
hoping gemini 3 will help me to clear tech debt created by codex and claude
Technical debt stacks up way faster than I expected when using Claude
Earlier this year we made the mistake of assuming that all AI code was good code. The amount of technical debt we got in 2 weeks was complete insanity.
Skipping this = 3 weeks of tech debt in 2 days. Vibe-coding is a trap, plan first or regret later
I'm pretty much converted to Cursor for wrangling Clojure backend tech debt
Every code base I’ve ever had the pleasure of working on that was more than 2 years old has so much slop spaghetti code
gave claude the option of letting me fix the technical debt with the api or just let him build an over-engineered data object.
AI slop is another term for technical debt... it’s all about building things that can be maintained in the long term.
owning 50,000 lines of generated code isn't ownership. it's technical debt you didn't write.

turns out I did a bunch of big greenfield projects in like 45 days to 2 months in $400 in claude max...and we could talk about code quality or code smells or whatever artisanal bs, but it ships and its just as good or BETTER
My noob coder friend... copilot:- sends all his spaghetti code to microsoft servers
It honestly feels like having a senior dev watching every commit. 🧠
the key differentiator is who uses AI. That person needs to have the ability to understand if the output is introducing technical debt or not.
You are probably using it 100x more than me... mostly using GH Copilot Chat... for my old technical debt main VanillaJS website.
I am undoing 10 years of technical debt this week
Codex isn't as brain dead as claude but still tech debt mountain
